responses.content:
```yaml
leads:
  - headline: Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) via Gem Name
    analysis: |
      The application does not appear to sanitize gem names before displaying them on the web interface.
      An attacker could upload a gem with a name containing malicious JavaScript code, such as `<script>alert('XSS')</script>`.
      When other users view the list of available gems, the attacker's JavaScript code would be executed in their browsers.
    cwe: CWE-79
    function_names: []
    filenames: []
    classification: slightly promising
  - headline: Potential Denial of Service via Uncontrolled Resource Consumption
    analysis: |
      The Geminabox server allows users to upload gems without any apparent size restrictions.
      An attacker could potentially upload a very large gem file, consuming excessive disk space and potentially causing a denial of service.
    cwe: CWE-770
    function_names: []
    filenames: []
    classification: not promising
```

leads.headline: Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) via Gem Name
leads.analysis:
The application does not appear to sanitize gem names before displaying them on the web interface.
An attacker could upload a gem with a name containing malicious JavaScript code, such as <script>alert('XSS')</script>.
When other users view the list of available gems, the attacker's JavaScript code would be executed in their browsers.

leads.headline: Potential Denial of Service via Uncontrolled Resource Consumption
leads.analysis:
The Geminabox server allows users to upload gems without any apparent size restrictions.
An attacker could potentially upload a very large gem file, consuming excessive disk space and potentially causing a denial of service.
